rules.title: Learning objectives must be measurable
rules.body: All learning objectives must use observable, measurable action verbs from Bloom's taxonomy (e.g., identify, demonstrate, calculate). Avoid vague verbs such as understand, know, learn, appreciate, or be familiar with.

rules.title: Objectives must specify conditions
rules.body: Each learning objective must state the conditions under which the learner will perform the task, including available tools, references, equipment, and environmental constraints.

rules.title: Objectives must include performance standards
rules.body: Each learning objective must include a measurable performance standard (accuracy, speed, or quality threshold) the learner must achieve.

rules.title: Content must align with stated objectives
rules.body: All instructional content must directly support at least one stated learning objective. Content that does not map to an objective must be removed or an objective added.

rules.title: Content must be technically accurate
rules.body: All technical information, procedures, specifications, and data must be verified against authoritative sources. No contradictory statements are permitted within the same document.

rules.title: Acronyms must be defined on first use
rules.body: All acronyms and abbreviations must be spelled out in full on first use, followed by the acronym in parentheses. A glossary must be provided for documents exceeding 10 pages.

rules.title: Reading level must be appropriate
rules.body: Instructional content must not exceed a 12th-grade reading level unless the target audience requires specialized terminology. Sentences should average 15-20 words.

rules.title: Jargon must be contextually explained
rules.body: Domain-specific terminology must be defined in context or in a supporting glossary when first introduced. Assume the reader has baseline but not expert knowledge.

rules.title: Procedures must use numbered steps
rules.body: All procedural instructions must be presented as numbered sequential steps. Each step must contain a single action. Do not embed procedures within narrative paragraphs.

rules.title: Paragraphs must not exceed 150 words
rules.body: No single paragraph in instructional content should exceed 150 words. Long paragraphs must be broken into logical sub-sections with appropriate headings.

rules.title: Headings must follow hierarchical structure
rules.body: Document headings must follow a consistent hierarchical structure (H1 > H2 > H3). No heading level may be skipped. Each section must have a descriptive heading.

rules.title: Safety warnings must precede hazardous steps
rules.body: All safety warnings, cautions, and notes must appear before the procedural step they pertain to, never after. Use standard signal words: DANGER, WARNING, CAUTION, NOTE.

rules.title: Critical steps must be clearly identified
rules.body: Steps that are critical to safety or mission success must be visually distinguished (bold, boxed, or flagged) and explicitly labeled as critical.

rules.title: Examples must illustrate key concepts
rules.body: Each major concept or procedure must include at least one example or illustration. Examples must be realistic and relevant to the learner's operational context.

rules.title: Practice opportunities must be provided
rules.body: Instructional content must include practice exercises or knowledge checks after each major section. Feedback must be provided for incorrect responses.

rules.title: References must be current and complete
rules.body: All references to external documents, regulations, or standards must include full citation (title, document number, date, section). References older than 5 years must be verified as current.

rules.title: Version control information required
rules.body: All instructional documents must display version number, effective date, and responsible authority. Revision history must be maintained for auditable changes.
